question: Question_08_(ii)
statement:
You are driving down the highway when you see a sleeping moose. You
apply the brakes and carefully stop your car 20m away from the animal.
While you are looking for your camera the moose wakes up. It instantly
charges toward your car at a constant speed of 8m/s. One second later,
you start backing away from the moose at a constant acceleration of
2m/s\textsuperscript{2}.

\textbf{(ii)} At what time \emph{T} does the moose hit your car?
sols:
From our answer in part i), the distance between the moose and the car
is given by d(t), where

\begin{align*}\displaystyle d(t) = -t^{2} + 8t - 12.\end{align*} To solve for the time when
the moose hits the car we solve the equation d(T) = 0 to get T.

\begin{align*}
d(T) = -T^{2} + 8T - 12 &= 0 \\
-(T - 6)(T - 2) &= 0 \quad \rightarrow \quad T = 2,6\end{align*} Since the moose will not hit the car twice, we choose the
smaller of the two times, and say the moose will hit the car at

\begin{align*}{\color{blue}T =2.}\end{align*}
hints:
Use your answer from part i) to answer this question.

Also consider: what is the distance between the car and the moose when
the moose and the car collide?
